ai-mn40:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town called Usa.
ai-mn40:2.2_0: And when they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics.
ai-mn40:2.3_0: Given this label and this claim, you should train like this: ‘We will practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic. That way our label will be accurate and our claim correct.
ai-mn40:2.4_0: ‘We will practice in line with the teachings,
ai-mn40:2.5_0: In this way our nature will be true.
ai-mn40:2.6_0: And our use of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick shall be of great fruit and benefit for those who offered them. And our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.’
ai-mn40:3.1_0: And how does a mendicant not practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic?
ai-mn40:3.2_0: There are some mendicants who have not given up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view.
ai-mn40:3.3_0: These stains, defects, and dregs of an ascetic are grounds for rebirth in places of loss, and are experienced in bad places. As long as they have not given these up, they do not practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic, I say.
ai-mn40:4.1_0: I say that such a mendicant’s going forth may be compared to the kind of weapon called ‘death-dealer’—double-edged, hardened, and keen—covered and wrapped in the outer robe.
ai-mn40:4.2_0: and surrounded by my outer robe.
ai-mn40:4.3_0: That’s what this person is like, I say.
ai-mn40:5.1_0: I say that you don’t deserve the label ‘outer robe wearer’ just because you wear an outer robe.
ai-mn40:5.2_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘naked ascetic’ just because you go naked.
ai-mn40:5.3_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘dust and dirt wearer’ just because you’re caked in dust and dirt.
ai-mn40:5.4_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘water immerser’ just because you immerse yourself in water.
ai-mn40:5.5_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘tree root dweller’ just because you stay at the root of a tree.
ai-mn40:5.6_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘open air dweller’ just because you stay in the open air.
ai-mn40:5.7_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘stander’ just because you continually stand.
ai-mn40:5.8_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘interval eater’ just because you eat food at set intervals.
ai-mn40:5.9_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘reciter’ just because you recite scriptures.
ai-mn40:5.10_0: You don’t deserve the label ‘matted-hair ascetic’ just because you have matted hair.
ai-mn40:6.1_0: Imagine that just by wearing an outer robe someone with covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view could give up these things. If that were the case, your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would make you an outer robe wearer as soon as you were born. They’d encourage you:
ai-mn40:6.2_0: ‘Please, my dear, wear an outer robe! By doing so you will give up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view.’
ai-mn40:6.3_0: But sometimes I see someone with these bad qualities who is an outer robe wearer. That’s why I say that you don’t deserve the label ‘outer robe wearer’ just because you wear an outer robe.
ai-mn40:6.4_0: Imagine that just by going naked ...
ai-mn40:6.7_0: staying at the root of a tree ...
ai-mn40:6.12_0: having matted hair someone with covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view could give up these things. If that were the case, your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would make you a matted-hair ascetic as soon as you were born. They’d encourage you:
ai-mn40:6.13_0: ‘Please, my dear, become a matted-hair ascetic! By doing so you will give up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view.’
ai-mn40:6.13_1: wicked desires, wrong view will give up wrong view.’
ai-mn40:6.14_0: But sometimes I see someone with these bad qualities who is an covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view. That’s why I say that you don’t deserve the ascetic life.
ai-mn40:7.1_0: And how does a mendicant practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic?
ai-mn40:7.2_0: There are some mendicants who have given up covetousness, ill will, irritability, hostility, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, bad desires, and wrong view.
ai-mn40:7.3_0: These stains, defects, and dregs of an ascetic are grounds for rebirth in places of loss, and are experienced in bad places. When they have given these up, they are practicing in the way that is proper for an ascetic, I say.
ai-mn40:8.1_0: They see themselves purified from all these bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-mn40:8.2_0: Seeing this, joy springs up. Being joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-mn40:9.1_0: They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-mn40:9.1_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn40:10-12.1_0: I meditate spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, I spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn40:10-12.2_0: Meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing ...
ai-mn40:10-12.3_1: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-mn40:13.1_0: Suppose there was a lotus pond with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.
ai-mn40:13.2_0: Then along comes a person—whether from the east, west, north, or south—struggling in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.
ai-mn40:13.3_0: I’ve drunk that lotus pond for all day and by night. ...
ai-mn40:13.3_1: Suppose a trustworthy and reliable man were to come from the west,
ai-mn40:13.3_2: a trustworthy and reliable man were to come from the north ...
ai-mn40:13.3_3: and a trustworthy and reliable man were to come from the south.
ai-mn40:13.3_4: Then even if a person were to come along when they were in the oppressive heat, weary, thirsty, and parched.
ai-mn40:13.3_5: They’d undertake that lotus pond to be exhausted for a bond.
ai-mn40:13.4_0: In the same way, suppose someone has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness—whether from a family of aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, or workers—and has arrived at the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One.
ai-mn40:13.4_1: Because of that inner peace they are practicing the way proper for an ascetic, I say.
ai-mn40:13.4_5: And suppose someone has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness—whether from a family of the teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One, and they acquire equanimity.
ai-mn40:13.5_0: Because of that inner peace they are practicing the way proper for an ascetic, I say.
ai-mn40:14.1_0: And suppose someone has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness—whether from a family of aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, or workers—
ai-mn40:14.2_0: and they realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn40:14.3_0: They’re an ascetic because of the ending of defilements.
ai-mn40:14.3_4: And why they’ve gone forth from the lay life to homelessness, and realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn40:14.3_5: And this is the ending of defilements.”
ai-mn40:14.4_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn40:14.5_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn40:14.6_0: The tenth section on the Noble One is finished.
ai-mn40:14.7_0: The fourth sub-chapter on the Long Division is finished.
ai-mn40:15.4_0: The hair grew out his hair.
